g:HTMLPanel.b:Paragraph: Playing a video file from a disk in a browser is a pretty hard task. Because of that, we require two plug-ins to install.
(Also, please note that the video player is still very experimental and won't always work.)
g:HTMLPanel.b:Heading: Java
g:HTMLPanel.b:Paragraph: For selecting the file from your disk, you need to have Java installed and Java applets allowed in your browser. You can test, whether you have Java installed, on this site on java.com; installation instructions for Java are available here.
If you don't want to install Java, you can still use the player, but you will need to write the address to the input field yourself.
g:HTMLPanel.b:Heading: VLC plugin
g:HTMLPanel.b:Paragraph: You need to have VLC web plugin installed for the actual playback. Installation of VLC is straigthforward for the major platforms.

b:Paragraph.b:NavLink: You can test, whether you have VLC plugin installed, here.

g:HTMLPanel.b:Heading: Windows installation
g:HTMLPanel.b:Paragraph: If you don't have the VLC plugin installed, you need to run VLC installer (download it from VideoLAN website), even if you have VLC already installed. While installing VLC, you have to check either "Mozilla plugin" (if you are not using IE) or "ActiveX plugin" (if you are using IE).
g:HTMLPanel.b:Heading: Ubuntu/debian/APT installation
g:HTMLPanel.b:Paragraph: If you don't have the VLC plugin installed and you have a linux installation with support for apt, like Debian or Ubuntu, you can install VLC plugin by installing mozilla-plugin-vlc package (for example by apt-get install mozilla-plugin-vlc, or in Aptitude).
g:HTMLPanel.b:Heading: Mac OS X
g:HTMLPanel.b:Paragraph: For Mac OS X, you need to install both VLC and VLC plugin from videolan website
g:HTMLPanel.b:Heading: Player
g:HTMLPanel.b:Paragraph: Player doesn't play exactly the time of the subtitle, but 30 second long context around the subtitle. You can stop the player or replay the whole context.
